content.user_title: Write Clojure with REPL-driven best practices
content.value_statement: Clojure development can feel unfamiliar without REPL-driven workflows and proper conventions. This skill provides step-by-step guidance for bottom-up development, functional programming patterns, and critical editing rules to write correct Clojure code.
actual_capabilities: Guides REPL-driven development workflow from small functions to complex systems
Provides bottom-up development loop with file evaluation steps
Lists critical editing rules for Clojure syntax correctness
References Clojure style guide and command documentation
Prefers clojure-mcp tools over shell commands for REPL integration
limitations: Does not execute Clojure code directly - requires clojure-mcp tools or existing REPL
Does not provide project scaffolding or configuration
Does not include testing frameworks or test generation
References shared documentation files that must exist separately

use_cases.title: Learn REPL workflow
use_cases.description: Start with fundamental functions, test in REPL, then integrate into source code gradually

use_cases.title: Apply style conventions
use_cases.description: Follow established Metabase coding conventions and functional programming principles

use_cases.title: Prevent syntax errors
use_cases.description: Use structural editing rules, verify readability, and maintain proper parentheses balance

prompt_templates.title: New function
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a Clojure function that [describe functionality]. Start by writing and testing it in the REPL with various inputs.

prompt_templates.title: REPL workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me develop [feature] using bottom-up REPL workflow. Start with fundamental functions, test each in the REPL, then compose them.

prompt_templates.title: Style guide
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my Clojure code for style violations. Check against the style guide: proper function design, naming conventions, and formatting.

prompt_templates.title: Edit safely
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me edit [function/file] with proper Clojure syntax. Remember to verify readability after each change and check parentheses balance.

output_examples.input: Write a function to validate email addresses
output: 1. Start with basic validation rules (format, domain)
2. Test each rule individually in the REPL
3. Compose rules into a single validate-email function
4. Test edge cases (empty, invalid format, valid)
5. Move working function to appropriate namespace

best_practices: Start with smallest functions and test thoroughly in REPL before composing
Use clojure-mcp tools for REPL integration instead of shell commands when available
Verify readability with -check-readable after every Clojure code change
anti_patterns: Writing large functions without REPL testing at each step
Ignoring parentheses balance or skipping readability checks
Falling back to shell commands when clojure-mcp tools are available

faq.question: What tools does this skill require?
faq.answer: Requires clojure-mcp tools (clojure_eval, clojure_edit) or a running Clojure REPL for code execution.

faq.question: What are the limits of this skill?
faq.answer: Provides guidance only - does not execute code, generate projects, or configure environments.

faq.question: How do I integrate with existing projects?
faq.answer: Follow bottom-up workflow: test in REPL, integrate to namespaces, verify with -check-readable.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes - this is a prompt-only skill with no network calls or file writes outside of normal editing.

faq.question: Why is my code not working after editing?
faq.answer: Check parentheses balance and run -check-readable. Common issues include missing brackets and formatting errors.

faq.question: How is this different from other language skills?
faq.answer: Focuses on REPL-driven workflow, functional programming principles, and Metabase-specific Clojure conventions.
